awd_titl_txt: Geometric and Microlocal Study of Automorphic Periods
awd_abstract_narration:
In harmonic analysis, one represents functions on a space as a superposition of waves with varying frequencies. In number theory and the Langlands program, one is interested in functions on certain homogeneous spaces, where the "waves" are special eigenfunctions of Laplacians and Hecke operators, called automorphic forms. Some of the most mysterious and important invariants of the automorphic forms are the L-functions, a vast class of generalizations of the Riemann zeta function. A significant, but not well-understood, principle is that their superposition often represents a function that can be described independently, in terms of what are known as spherical varieties that give rise to a distribution called the period distribution.  The amplitudes of the spectral decomposition of this distribution turn out to be special values of L-functions. The project will investigate conjectural connections between period distributions and L-functions using ideas of quantization (whose roots lie in mathematical physics). The PI also plans yearly meetings to train students and postdocs on the topics related to this proposal. 

According to the visionary program developed since the '60s by Abel Prize recipient Robert P. Langlands, L-functions should be understood as invariants of automorphic representations; those are the "eigenfrequencies" of "arithmetic manifolds", or else the representations of a (reductive) Lie group G, and of its algebra of Hecke operators, which appear as functions on a quotient L\G, where L is an arithmetic lattice. The precise incarnation of L-functions in this setting is by means of certain distributions called "periods", which the PI and others have studied and organized into a coherent theory in recent years. The present award aims to utilize ideas of symplectic geometry in the study of these periods. Among other goals, this project will study: (1) the duality between periods and L-functions as a duality between Hamiltonian spaces for the group and its dual group (building up on recent work with Ben-Zvi and Venkatesh); (2) the local spectrum of spherical varieties by combining the relative trace formula of Waldspurger with the geometry of the moment map studied by Knop; (3) the "transfer operators" of functoriality, in the spirit of Langlands' "beyond endoscopy", between the relative trace formulas of different groups and spaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI, jointly with David Ben-Zvi and Akshay Venkatesh, developed a framework for understanding the theory of the Riemann zeta function and its generalizations, called automorphic L-functions, as a refinement of the Langlands program. The Langlands program proposes to understand harmonic-analytic objects, called automorphic representations, related to a (suitable) group G, in terms of objects related to diophantine equations by means of a "dual group" Ĝ. In order to incorporate L-functions into this framework, the PI and his collaborators have extended this duality to a duality of pairs of the form (G, M), where M is a "hyperspherical" space with an action of G, i.e., a symplectic variety with a Hamiltonian action of G enjoying various good properties. By introducing these objects on the diophantine side of Langlands duality, one obtains L-functions, while by introducing them on the harmonic-analytic side, one obtains certain "period integrals", such as the one used by Riemann to prove the functional equation of the zeta function. An outcome of this project was a 450-page preprint, where the authors explore this duality at various levels -- global fields, local field, and their geometric counterparts -- following the philosophy (proposed by Kapustin--Witten) of viewing the Langlands program as a "quantum field theory". At each level, the duality gives rise to conjectures, most of which are new, but some particular cases of which tie together conjectures that had already appeared in number theory, geometric representation theory, and mathematical physics, creating a unifying framework for fruitful exchange of insights among these fields.

In addition, the PI furthered his own project for developing a theory of "transfer operators" to address the functoriality conjecture in the Langlands program (and its generalizations in the "relative" Langlands program). This is a conjecture entirely on the harmonic-analytic side, and it predicts some correspondences between representations occuring on different groups and spaces. A proposal by Langlands states that those should be established by a novel type of comparison between trace formulas, and the PI has worked on understanding the nature of such comparisons, broadened to the setting of the relative trace formula. In a couple of papers on the topic, the PI discovered an interpretation of formulas for such operators that he had previously computed, in terms of the idea of "quantization" -- namely, in an appropriate sense, these operators appear to quantize a correspondence between "cotangent stacks" associated to the relative trace formulas under review. While these examples are currently limited to low-rank cases, there is hope that this interpretation will open the path to understanding transfer operators in highly nontrivial higher-rank cases.

In terms of broader impacts, the PI was a co-organizer of the 2022 IHES Summer School on the Langlands program, that attempted to demonstrate the state of the art on a large part of this vast program, and will result to proceedings volumes for the benefit of the broader scientific community. In the lead-up to this school, the PI co-organized online seminars to help junior mathematicians catch up with the formidable background required to follow the Langlands program. Moreover, the PI has co-organized, on a yearly basis, the "Junior Number Theory Days", a weekend conference for graduating PhD students in number theory to showcase their work. He has also been the co-organizer of various other conferences on number theory, representation theory, and automorphic forms.
